Text: Bioactive peptides have attracted extensive attention worldwide due to not only their health promoting potential, but also their natural and safe properties (Mora, Gallego, & Toldrá, 2018; Sultan, Huma, Butt, Aleem, & Abbas, 2018; Toldrá, Reig, Aristoy, & Mora, 2018). In recent years, peptides derived from food protein sources have been massively studied as functional food ingredients driving by the increasing demand for improving human health and wellness through daily diet supplement (Chalamaiah, Yu, & Wu, 2018; Kim & Wijesekara, 2010; Zhang et al., 2018). To date, peptides derived from various food proteins have been reported to exhibit positive effect on the prevention of diseases and modulation of physiological functions, including antioxidant, anti-hypertension, anti-cancer, anti-gout, anti-diabetes, anti-inflammation, alcohol hydrogenase (ADH) activating and/or stabilization, hepatoprotection, cardioprotection, osteoprotection, immunomodulation, antimicrobial and antiviral activity, etc. (Chalamaiah et al., 2018; Mora et al., 2018; Pan et al., 2018; Todorov, Wachsman, Knoetze, Meincken, & Dicks, 2005; Yu, Li, He, Huang, & Zhang, 2013). Bioactive peptides are inactive within protein sequence but once released through fermentation, enzymatic hydrolysis, or gastrointestinal digestion, they can exert their activity in the target organ. Enzymatic hydrolysis is still the most commonly used method for peptide preparation due to the controllable and reproducible process in addition to high production efficiency, regardless the introduction of salt when adjusting pH, which may be difficult to remove (Wang, Yu, Xing, & Li, 2017). Also, peptides are more absorbable and bioavailable than proteins (Chalamaiah et al., 2018). Chicken meat is well accepted worldwide as an important source of high quality dietary protein. Chicken breast contains over 90% of crude proteins (dry basis), which are rich in essential amino acids, offering a well-balanced amino acid composition, and is considered a good source of bioactive peptides (Cui, Zhou, Zhao, & Yang, 2009; Murphy, Marks, & Marcy, 1998; Sun, Pan, Guo, & Li, 2012). Previous studies indicated that Alcalase digestion of chicken breast muscle could generate great amounts of bioactive peptides (alcohol dehydrogenase stabilization and antioxidant activity) that benefit to the prevention and amelioration of alcohol-induced liver injury (Xiao et al., 2019; Xiao, Zhou, Zhao, Su, & Sun, 2018). In addition, chicken liver hydrolysate could also enhance the catalytic activity of hepatic alcohol metabolic enzyme (ADH and ALDH) and antioxidative enzymes (SOD, CAT and GPx) (Lin et al., 2017). However, bioactive peptides could also be generated during the transportation and storage of chicken breast under the action of endogenous peptidases (Mora, Bolumar, Heres, & Toldrá, 2017; Toldrá, 2006). Moreover, pre-treatment before meat consumption such as cooking, fermentation, and curing, may also affect the action of endogenous enzymes and subsequently result in the generation of bioactive peptides (Sayd, Chambon, & Santé-Lhoutellier, 2016). For instance, protein and peptide oxidation could happen during the cooking of chicken breast muscle, resulting in the modification of structural properties and bioactivity (Serpen, Gökmen, & Fogliano, 2012). On the other hand, ingested peptides should be able to circulate intact through the gastrointestinal tract in order to be absorbed, reach the blood stream, and exert their biological function in target organs. Simulated digestion using gastrointestinal enzymes is generally applied to confirm the biological accessibility and availability of bioactive peptides after ingestion. However, its effect on bioactivity must also be considered because peptides are easily degraded due to the action of endogenous gastrointestinal enzymes (Escudero, Sentandreu, Arihara, & Toldrá, 2010; Mora et al., 2017). The main purposes of this study were to evaluate the changes occurred in chicken breast extracted peptides as a consequence of cooking and simulated gastrointestinal digestion, and the effect of these factors on alcohol dehydrogenase stabilization capacity and antioxidant activity of peptides. Peptides were identified using in tandem mass spectrometry and analyzed using a label-free quantitation approach.

2.1 Materials Chicken breast was obtained from a local market 24 h after slathering (Valencia, Spain). Enzymes for in vitro digestion: salivary α-amylase, porcine pepsin, porcine pancreatic α-amylase, porcine pancreatic lipase, and porcine bile extract were obtained from Sigma Aldrich, Co. Ltd (St. Louis, MO, USA), whereas trypsin and chymotrypsin were from Fluka (Sigma-Aldrich, Co., St. Louis, MO, USA). 2,2′-Diphenyl-1-picrylhydrazyl (DPPH), potassium ferricyanide, ferric chloride, trichloroacetic acid (TCA), 2,6-di-tertbutyl-4-methylphenol (BHT), 2,2′-azinobis (3-ethylbenzothiazoline-6-sulfonic acid) diammonium salt (ABTS), (±)-6-hydroxy-2,5,7,8-tetramethylchromane-2-carboxylic acid (Trolox), fluorescein, 2,2′-azobis (2-methylpropionamidine) dihydrochloride (AAPH), alcohol dehydrogenase (from Saccharomyces cerevisiae), and β-nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich, Co. Ltd (St. Louis, MO, USA). Acetonitrile, hydrochloric acid 37%, and trifluoroacetic acid (TFA) were of HPLC grade from Scharlab (Barcelona, Spain). All other chemicals and reagents were of analytical grade and obtained from Scharlab (Barcelona, Spain).

sections: Preparation of chicken breast muscle bioactive peptides
Text: 2.2 Preparation of chicken breast muscle bioactive peptides 2.2.1 Cooking Cooking was carried out according to the method described by Mora et al. (2017). As indicated in Fig. 1 , one third of the chicken breast was preserved as control, while the rest was placed in a vacuum bag and cooked for 30 min in a water bath until the internal temperature of the chicken breast reached 70 °C. This temperature is used in traditional cooked ham production to assure the quality and safety characteristics of the product. The temperature was monitored using a hand held digital thermometer. After cooking, the chicken breast was cooled to 25 °C in an ice bath (0 °C) and stored at − 18 °C for further peptide extraction and hydrolysis. 2.2.2 Simulated gastrointestinal digestion The digestion was carried out using a two-stage assay in the digestor (Carousel 6 Plus Reaction Station, Radleys, UK) adapted from the standard consensus protocol for static simulated digestion released by Infogest (Minekus et al., 2014). In this assay, oral phase digestion was not performed because chicken breast contains over 90% of crude protein (in dry basis) and the expected effect of salivary enzymes was negligible and could negatively influence further identification of peptide sequences. Chicken breast was cut into small pieces and minced before used. Firstly, 5 g of chicken breast sample was weighed and suspended in 10 mL of 0.01 N HCl at pH 3. The gastric phase was started by adding porcine pepsin (2000 U mL − 1), followed by 15 μL of 50 mM CaCl2. After 2 h of digestion at 37 °C and constant stirring, the enzyme was inactivated by adjusting pH to 7.0 with 1 M NaOH. Then the intestinal phase was initiated by adding an enzyme mixture of 100 U mL−1 of trypsin, 25 U mL−1 of chymotrypsin, 200 U mL−1 of porcine pancreatic α-amylase, 2000 U mL−1 of porcine pancreatic lipase and 10 mM of porcine bile extract, followed by 70 μL of 50 mM CaCl2. Samples were incubated for 2 h at 37 °C and the digestion was completed by heating in a water bath at 95 °C for 2 min. 2.2.3 Peptide extraction and deproteinization Control and cooked chicken breast samples were minced and 30 g of each sample was homogenized with 120 mL of 0.01 N HCl (IUL Instrument homogenizer, Barcelona, Spain) for 8 min under cold conditions to extract peptides. After peptide extraction or simulated digestion, the mixtures were centrifuged at 12 000 g and 4 °C for 20 min. The supernatants were collected and 3 volumes of ethanol (1 : 3) were added and the mixtures were store at 4 °C for 20 h to remove the proteins. Subsequently, the samples were centrifuged at 12 000 g and 4 °C for 20 min. The supernatant was filtered with Nylon filters of 0.45 μm and ethanol was evaporated using a rotatory evaporator. Finally, the samples were lyophilized and stored at −18 °C for further analysis.

2.3 Determination of antioxidant activity The antioxidant activity was determined in triplicate for all the assays. For that, stock solutions of 500 mg/mL (on basis of lyophilized powder) in bidistilled water were prepared for all the samples. 2.3.1 Oxygen radical absorbance capacity (ORAC) assay ORAC assay was performed as described by Dávalos et al. (2004) with some modifications. Briefly, 140 μL of sample was mixed with 70 μL of fluorescein (200 nM) in a microplate and pre-incubated at 37 °C for 15 min. Then, 70 μL of AAPH (80 mM) was added and the fluorescence was measured exactly every min for 100 min using a Fluoroskan Ascent plate reader (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA). The excitation and emission wavelengths were 485 and 538 nm, respectively. Trolox was used as a positive control and the ORAC values were expressed as μM TE (Trolox equivalents)/g of sample. 2.3.2 ABTS radical scavenging capacity The ABTS assay was carried out according to Gallego, Mora, Hayes, Reig, and Toldrá (2017). Briefly, 7 mM ABTS stock was prepared in 2.45 mM potassium persulfate and stored in the dark at room temperature for 12–16 h to produce ABTS+●. The ABTS+● solution was diluted with 50 mM phosphate buffer saline (PBS, pH 7.4) to obtain an absorbance of 0.70 ± 0.02 at 734 nm. Then, 10 μL of sample was mixed with 990 μL of ABTS+● solution, measuring the absorbance at 734 nm after 6 min of incubation in dark. Trolox was used as positive control, while PBS as negative control. Results were expressed as μM TE/g of sample. 2.3.3 DPPH radical scavenging activity DPPH scavenging activity analysis was carried out according to Gallego et al. (2017). Briefly, 100 μL of sample was mixed with 500 μL of ethanol and 125 μL DPPH solution (2%, w/v in ethanol). The mixture was kept for 60 min in the dark before the measuring of absorbance at 517 nm. Distilled water and BHT were used as negative and positive control, respectively. Results were expressed as DPPH scavenging activity, calculated using the following equation: DPPH radical scavenging activity (%) = (Absorbance control − Absorbance sample) × 100/Absorbance control. 2.3.4 Ferric-reducing antioxidant power The ferric-reducing antioxidant power was measured conducted according to Mora et al. (2017). Briefly, 100 μL of sample was mixed with 250 μL of potassium phosphate buffer (0.2 M, pH 6.6) and 250 μL of potassium ferricyanide (1% w/v) and incubated at 50 °C for 30 min. Then, 250 μL of 10% TCA was added, mixed, and centrifuged at 12 000 g for 10 min. After that, 250 μL of the supernatant were taken and 250 μL of distilled water and 50 μL of 0.1% (w/v) ferrous chloride were added. Absorbance was measured at 700 nm after 10 min. Results were expressed as absorbance values at 700 nm.

2.4 ADH stabilization activity assay The ADH stabilization activity assay was carried according to our previous study (Xiao et al., 2019). In brief, peptide samples (0.1 mg/mL in bidistilled water, 50 μL) were pre-incubated with the same volume of ADH (0.2 U/mL dissolved in 10 mM PBS, pH 7.4) at 37 °C for 60 min before the detection of enzyme activity. ADH activity was determined by adding 150 μL of preincubated reaction reagent (containing 22.4 mM sodium pyrophosphate buffer, 3.3% ethanol and 7.8 mM NAD+). The resultant β-nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide hydrate (NADH) was recorded at 340 nm every 10 s for 10 min under 37 °C incubation using a CLARIOstar microplate reader (BMG LABTECH, Ortenberg, Germany). The reaction curve was fitted and the first derivative of the fitting curve at 0 min was calculated as the initial reaction rate. The original ADH activity was considered 100%, bi-distilled water instead of peptides was used as a negative control. Relative activity was calculated according to the following formula: (1) Relative activity % = Vs / V 0 × 100 % Here, V0 was the original ADH activity, while VS was that of the negative control or tested samples. All the determinations were carried out in triplicate.

2.5 Reversed-phase high-performance liquid chromatography (RP-HPLC) analysis An Agilent 1100 HPLC system (Agilent Tech., California, USA) with a Symmetry C18 column (250 × 4.6 mm, 5 μm; Waters Co. Milford, MA, USA) was used to analyze the differences in peptide profiles after different treatments. The mobile phases consisted of solvent A: 0.1% TFA in milli Q water (v/v) and solvent B: 0.085% TFA in 60% acetonitrile (milli Q water:ACN; v/v). Samples (50 mg/mL × 20 μL) were injected and separated under a flow rate of 1 mL/min using the following gradient: 0% solvent B for the first 5 min, and linearly increase to 50% solvent B in 25 min. Peptide fractions were monitored at 214 nm.

2.6 Identification of peptides by nLC–MS/MS Peptides were identified using a nano-liquid chromatography tandem mass spectrometry system (nLC-MS/MS, AB Sciex Instruments, MA, USA), according to Gallego et al. (Gallego, Mora, Aristoy, & Toldrá, 2015a). Briefly, samples (5 μL, 0.3 mg/mL) were loaded onto an Eksigen trap column (3 µm C18-CL, 350 μm × 0.5 mm) for 5 min before injected into the analytical column (3 µm C18-CL, 75 μm × 123 mm; Nikkyo Technos Co, Ltd. Japan). The mobile phases consisted of solvent A: 0.1% v/v formic acid (FA) in water and solvent B: 0.1% FA in acetonitrile (ACN). Peptides were separated linearly from 5% to 35% solvent B over the first 90 min, and then from 35% to 65% solvent B for 10 min under a flow rate of 0.3 μL/min at 30 °C. The flow was ionized applying 2.8 kV. Q-ToF was operated in positive polarity and information-dependent acquisition mode. MS1 scan was acquired from 100 to 1200 m/z for 250 ms, while MS2 scan was required from 100 to 1500 m/z for 50 ms on 50 of the most intense ions charging from 1 to 5.

sections: Label free quantitation of the identified peptides
Text: 2.7 Label free quantitation of the identified peptides Relative quantitation was performed using a label-free method according to Gallego et al. (2015a). The quantitation of peptide is based on the relative integrate area of extracted ion chromatogram (XIC) in each sample. For that, quantitative data was obtained using Peak View 1.1 software (AB Sciex, Framingham, MA, USA) and then analyzed using Marker View 1.3 software (AB Sciex, Framingham, MA, USA). No multiple corrections are performed. Only peptides with confidence of 95% or greater were quantified. The area of XICs for each peptide was obtained from the median according to the predefined algorithm in Peak View 1.1 software. Each sample was quantified in triplicate.

2.8 Statistical analysis Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and loading plot analysis were performed using SIMCA P + 13.0 (Umetrics AB, Sweden) software. Statistical analysis was performed using an SPSS package (SPSS 13.0 for Windows, SPSS Inc, Chicago, IL). The homogeneity of the data was tested before mean comparison applying the one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) following Duncan’s test. Difference of p < 0.05 was considered statistically significant. Standard deviation (SD) was shown as error bars on the figures.

sections: Effect of cooking and simulated gastrointestinal digestion on the antioxidant activity of chicken breast
Text: 3.1 Effect of cooking and simulated gastrointestinal digestion on the antioxidant activity of chicken breast It is recommended to use different assays to evaluate the antioxidant activity of a sample, since no single standard method can characterize its overall antioxidant capacity (Gallego, Mora, Reig, & Toldrá, 2018). Among the most commonly used assays, some are based on hydrogen atom transfer mechanism (HAT, i.e. oxygen radical absorbance capacity (ORAC), total radical trapping antioxidant parameter (TRAP) and β-carotene bleaching assay), while the others are based on electron transfer (ET, i.e. DPPH radical scavenging, ferric reducing power, and ABTS radical scavenging assays) (MacDonald-Wicks, Wood, & Garg, 2006). In this article, four different antioxidant assays were applied, including ORAC, ABTS, DPPH, ferric reducing power assays. As can be seen in Fig. 2 , non-significant differences were observed between control and the cooked samples on all the assays except the ferric reducing powerassay, in which OD 700 increased from 0.43 to 0.50 after cooking (Fig. 2B). The measurement of in vitro antioxidant activity needs the use of more than one methodology to get a complete overview of the antioxidant behavior and affinity of the compound. These results are in agreement with a previous study describing that cooking does not significantly influence the antioxidant and antihypertensive activity of beef extract (Mora et al., 2017). The obtained results could be due to the stability of chicken peptides towards heat treatment. However, the increase in ferric reducing power assay indicated that some positive changes occurred on peptides during cooking. Previous studies indicated that cooking can trigger the generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS), resulting in the oxidative modifications in proteins and peptides, and masking the antioxidant capacity of peptides (Mora et al., 2017; Soladoye, Juárez, Aalhus, Shand, & Estévez, 2015). As an example, active free thiol group in Cys and Met are very sensitive to ROS and may be oxidized to disulfide, sulfenic acid, sulfinic acid, methionine sulfoxide, and methionine sulfone, etc. during cooking under the action of ROS, resulting in the loss of antioxidant activity (Simonetti, Gambacorta, & Perna, 2016). However, some researches described an increase in antioxidant activity after thermal process because the denaturation of protein or peptide and generation of peptides with antioxidant activity (Gallego et al., 2017; Sayd et al., 2016). In the present study, results suggested the stability of the obtained peptides during cooking, and the maintenance of antioxidant activity possibly due to the generation of peptides that compensate the loss of activity induced by thermal treatment. However, after further simulated gastrointestinal digestion, a significant decrease of DPPH radical scavenging rate (from 36.1% to 4.4%) and ferric reducing power (OD 700 from 0.50 to 0.15), and a sharp increase of ORAC (from 112.5 to 682.0 uM TE/g) and ABTS radical scavenging activity (from 164.0 to 848.9 uM TE/g) were observed. These results further indicated the importance to characterize the antioxidant capacity using different assays. The apparently contradictory results could be due to the fact that the antioxidant activity of peptides is related not only to the peptide size and amino acid composition, but also amino acid sequence, peptide structure and hydrophobicity (or polarity), etc., which also determine the antioxidant mechanism (HAT or ET) (Gallego et al., 2017; Zheng, Zhao, Dong, Su, & Zhao, 2016). In the present study, HAT based assay (ORAC) results icreased, whereas ET based assays (DPPH radical scavenging and ferric reducing power) decreased with the exception of ABTS radical scavenging results. Though ABTS radical scavenging was classified as an ET-based assay, the reaction mechanism between ABTS+● and peptide is initiated by a labile hydrogen atom, as a result, ABTS radical scavenging assay could also be considered a HAT-based method (Gallego, Mauri, Aristoy, Toldrá, & Mora, 2020). Furthermore, previous studies reported that Cys, Met, and related peptides were found to display noticeable ferric reducing power and DPPH radical scavenging activity due to the strong reducing functional group of –SH in Cys, whereas Trp, Tyr and related peptides exhibit strong ORAC and ABTS radical scavenging activity (Zheng, Lin, Su, Zhao, & Zhao, 2015; Zheng et al., 2016). In the present study, gastrointestinal digestion simulation was performed using pepsin, chymotrypsin, and trypsin. The primary targets of these enzymes were Phe, Leu, Trp, Tyr, Lys, and Pro cleveage sites (Altınelataman et al., 2019). In this regard, the simulated digestion resulted in the release of Trp and Trp-containing peptides, which subsequently contributed to the increase of ORAC and ABTS radical scavenging activity. The obtained results also indicated that the gastrointestinal digestion was not increasing the ferric reducing power and DPPH radical scavenging activities. This fact could be due to that antioxidant peptides are degraded whereas little novel antioxidant sequences are generated or that there is a release of non-antioxidant peptide sequences that results in the dilution of active sequences and the decrease of ferric reducing power and DPPH radical scavenging activities. Similar results were also obtained during the study of antioxidant peptides derived from dry-cured ham (Gallego et al., 2020).

sections: Effect of cooking and simulated gastrointestinal digestion on ADH stabilization activity
Text: 3.2 Effect of cooking and simulated gastrointestinal digestion on ADH stabilization activity Regarding ADH stabilization activity, non-significant difference was observed after cooking, although simulated gastrointestinal digestion resulted in a significant decrease from 44.1% to 20.5% relative ADH activity (Fig. 3 ). This result was in line with that of DPPH and ferric-reducing power assay as aforementioned (Fig. 2A and B). Similar result was observed when bovine peptides were subjected to gastrointestinal digestion (Fu, Young, Dalsgaard, & Therkildsen, 2015). It was demonstrated that longer peptide tended to form a more favorable spatial conformation to interact with an enzyme, inducing a conformation change in the enzyme and modifying enzyme activity (Ma, Wu, & Li, 2018; Yu et al., 2013). In this research, gastrointestinal enzymes resulted in the degradation of relatively longer peptides, leading to the loss of favorable conformation for the interaction between peptide and ADH. Moreover, a recent study reported that tripeptide KPC stabilizes ADH possibly through binding to the active site of ADH and protecting ADH against oxidative inactivation (Xiao et al., 2019). In this regard, the decrease in ADH stabilization activity may also related to the release of oxidized sequences during simulated digestion, sharing the similar mechanism as that of the DPPH scavenging and ferric reducing power activity.

sections: Effect of cooking and gastrointestinal digestion on the peptide fractions
Text: 3.3 Effect of cooking and gastrointestinal digestion on the peptide fractions To further understand how cooking and gastrointestinal digestion could influence peptide bioactivity, the samples were analyzed by RP-HPLC, which is one of the most common methods used for peptide separation and analysis (Moayedi et al., 2018). Samples were prepared using lyophilized peptide powder and normalized to the same peptide powder concentration by subtracting the induction of digestive enzymes and salt. As shown in Fig. 4 , the profile of the cooked sample was almost overlapped with that of control, indicating that cooking did not lead to significant changes in peptide fractions. This result was in accordance with the maintenance of antioxidant (Fig. 2) and ADH stabilization activities (Fig. 3) after cooking. However, further gastrointestinal digestion led to significant changes in fraction intensity. After gastrointestinal digestion, a higher amount of peptides were observed due to newly released sequences from chicken proteins, as well as the degradation of peptides into shorter fragments or amino acids, resulting in a markedly decrease in intensity was found in the fractions eluted at about 3.5–6 min and 10.5–11.5 min, whereas an increase in intensity was found at about 8.5–10.5 min and 11.5–30 min. Similarly, Gallego et al. found that a large amount of small antioxidant peptides (<450 Da) were generated after the simulated gastrointestinal digestion of dry-cured ham (Gallego et al., 2017). As aforementioned, digestive enzymes used in present study tend to firstly release peptides containing Trp, Tyr, and Phe etc. residues. On the other hand, Trp, Tyr and related peptides can significantly increase ABTS and ORAC activity (Fig. 2C and D) (Zheng, Dong, Su, Zhao, & Zhao, 2016; Zheng et al., 2012).

sections: Effect of cooking and gastrointestinal digestion on peptide profile
Text: 3.4 Effect of cooking and gastrointestinal digestion on peptide profile Samples were fully characterized and quantified by nLC-MS/MS to determine the effect of cooking and gastrointestinal digestion on the peptide profile. The relative quantitation of peptides was performed using a label-free peptidomic approach by extracting peak intensity. A total of 777 peptides from 76 parent proteins were identified in control, cooked, and cooked plus digested samples. A Principal Component Analysis (PCA) was applied to evaluate the differences between the groups of samples, obtaining the information of the most influencing peptides. In Fig. 5 A, the PCA showed three statistically different groups, showing that cooking and further GI digestion resulted in significant differences regarding peptide concentration. Principal component 1 (PC 1) explained the 61.1% of the variability in the dataset, while PC 2 was responsible for the 22.4% within the dataset, allowing the differentiation between the three groups of samples. Thus, peptides identified in the ‘Cooked and Digested’ group (Fig. 5) might be the most important influencing bioactivity. Fig. 5B revealed all the peptides influencing the clustering of data. According to these results, the most abundant peptides responsible for the differences in the peptide profiles were derived from titin (green) and collagen (red) proteins. Interestingly, collagen and titin peptides could easily be oxidized during cooking and digestion, especially Met and Cys residues which are the most susceptible to oxidation by all forms of ROS due to the existence of sulfur atoms (Gallego, Mora, Aristoy, & Toldrá, 2015b; Zhang, Xiao, & Ahn, 2013). Another research found that a large number of peptides from collagen by-products showed the oxidation of Pro residue after cooking and in vitro GI digestion of Spanish dry-cured ham (Gallego et al., 2017). More recently, Pro residues from collagen were reported to be the main targets during in vitro oxidation of chicken breast (Márquez-Lázaro, Mora, Méndez-Cuadro, Rodríguez-Cavallo, & Toldrá, 2020). In this regard, the accumulation of oxidized peptides can reduce the antioxidant capacity in meat peptides (Serpen et al., 2012). Hence, all the 46 detected oxidized peptides were subjected to further analysis, and results are shown in Fig. 6 . The PCA separated two statistically different groups, with the ‘Cooked and Digested’ group located in a different cluster (Fig. 6A). PC 1 explained the 94.4% of the variability in the dataset, which allowed the differentiation between the ‘Cooked and Digested’ samples from the other. On the other hand, PC 2 was responsible for 2.7% of the variance within the dataset for the two discriminant components. The loading plot (Fig. 6B) revealed the main peptides responsible for the observed differences, indicated by the higher color density value. As can be seen in Fig. 7, the highest color density were represented by 9 peptides, including MIEM[Oxi]DGTENK (1167.316 Da), NGDRGETGPAGPAGPP[Oxi]GPAGA(1802.85 Da), GETGPAGP[Oxi]AGPP[Oxi]GPAGA (1360.424 Da), GSP[Oxi]GADGPIGAP[Oxi]GTP[Oxi]GPQ (1532.618 Da), AGPAGNP[Oxi]GADGQP[Oxi]GAK (1364.42 Da), GP[Oxi]SGPQGPSGAP[Oxi]GPK (1290.386 Da), GAP[Oxi]GPHGQVGPSGKP[Oxi]GN (1513.634 Da), HGDQGPP[Oxi]GNNGPAGPR (1527.57 Da), and GLP[Oxi]GAIGAP[Oxi]GPAGGAGDR (1490.618 Da), indicating the most influencing effect of these peptides on the difference between samples. The complete list of the 46 oxidized peptides and their relative quantitation is shown in Fig. 7 . A total of 40 among the 46 peptides were originated from chicken collagen, containing at least one oxidized Pro residue in each sequence. Three peptides were derived from chicken myosin with oxidized Met residue in the sequences, including NLTEEM[Oxi]AVLDETIAKLT (1891.134 Da), VFDKEGNGTVM[Oxi] (1196.340 Da), and KMEGDLNEM[Oxi] (1066.202 Da). Furthermore, almost all the oxidized peptides were observed with increased concentration after digestion, indicating further released of such peptides during digestion. In this regard, cooking could lead to protein oxidation of amino acid residues Met and Pro, and further simulated gastrointestinal digestion could result in the release of oxidized peptides that are inactive, diluting the concentration of active sequences, and subsequently decreasing activity in ferric reducing power, DPPH radical scavenging and ADH stabilization activity, while the release of Trp and Tyr containing peptides would contribute to the increase in ORAC and ABTS radical scavenging assays.

This study reports the effect of cooking and simulated gastrointestinal digestion on the generation of bioactive peptides in chicken breast and the influence on peptide bioactivity. The obtained results showed that cooking did not result in significant changes in the bioactivity detected, whereas gastrointestinal digestion could lead to an increase in ABTS and ORAC activity, but a decrease of DPPH, ferric reducing power, and ADH stabilization activity. The change in bioactivity may result mainly from peptides identified from titin and collagen, as well as from the newly generated peptides during gastrointestinal digestion. Protein oxidation occurred during cooking and the oxidized sequences were released during further digestion, resulting in the change of bioactivity. Results obtained further illustrated the promising potential to use bioactive chicken peptides as functional food ingredient, however, more work would be needed to synthesize and validate the antioxidant and ADH stabilization activity of these specific peptide sequences that may be responsible for the bioactivity of chicken breast.
